title: The secret to traveling the world fulltime
text:
Email a friend 
NICK Wharton and Dariece Swift had fulltime jobs and a mortgage until a trip to Mexico changed everything. 
Wanderlust got such a hold of the young Canadian couple that, upon returning home from their Mexican adventure, they promptly quit their nine-to-five jobs and decided to travel the world permanently . 
“We were left wanting more,” Swift told The Independent. 
“Visiting underground caves and having Mexican children run up to us with huge smiles on their faces really sparked something in us. 
“We returned home recharged with a new found love for the unknown.” 
Within nine months Wharton, now 30, and Swift, 31, had sold their home and were journeying through Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Laos, India, Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore. A photo posted by Nick & Dariece (@goatsontheroad) on Sep 23, 2014 at 7:42pm PDT 
The pair returned to Canada when funds ran low and temporarily returned to work — Wharton at a printing press and Swift at a legal office. 
But they travel bug still had a hold of them, and they weren’t to stay put for long. 
“After a couple of months back at work, we knew we couldn’t continue to live and work in Canada for the rest of our live,” Swift said. 
“That year abroad changed us and we found ourselves struggling to fit back in with the ‘normal’ way of life.” A photo posted by Nick & Dariece (@goatsontheroad) on Mar 8, 2015 at 6:53pm PDT 
That’s not to say their loved ones weren’t left “pretty shocked” by their big decision to leave home for good, the couple admitted. 
“Our decision to quit our jobs and sell our home, vehicle and belongings was a pretty sudden and drastic one, and although no one directly told us, we could see the concern on many of their faces,” Swift said. 
“Perhaps it was concern for our safety, concern for the fact that we had only been dating for a little over a year, or maybe it was simply the fact that they were going to miss us.” A photo posted by Nick & Dariece (@goatsontheroad) on Mar 14, 2015 at 3:38pm PDT 
After saying goodbye to Canada again, the couple set off on 16 months of travelling through Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Asia, before settling into China to teach English, all the while documenting their adventures in their travel blog, Goats on the Road . 
While they still teach English and house- and pet-sit occasionally, the blog is now their main source of income, generating advertising revenue of up to $AU6900 a month. 
Wharton and Swift have visited 45 countries so far and feel “nowhere near finished exploring the world”. A photo posted by Nick & Dariece (@goatsontheroad) on May 20, 2015 at 2:49pm PDT 
They said they “fell in love” with Grenada and especially enjoyed trekking through wilderness and meeting nomads in Mongolia. 
Swift also said they received “unbelievable” hospitality in Iran, where families would invite the couple into their homes for a nights’ stay or a chat over tea. 
Wharton admitted the distance from family and friends was be difficult but it was “less relevant” with the ability to communicate online. 
“Until there is a digital hug however, we’ll still return to Canada each year or so for a visit — or better yet, people come and visit us,” he said. 
Wharton also said seven years abroad had completely changed his point of view. A photo posted by Nick & Dariece (@goatsontheroad) on Aug 22, 2015 at 8:13pm PDT 
“We’ve learned that media doesn’t always portray places and people the way that they deserve to be represented and there is often an ulterior motive behind many of the things that we see on TV back home,” he said. 
“We’ve learned that despite our endless differences and fascinating cultural uniqueness, we are all the same in this world. We all have the same core values and we all love each other. 
“We’re all human and we’re all in this together. That’s probably the most important thing that we’ve learned from travelling, and our life is better off just by knowing that simple truth.” 
The couple now encouraging others to consider a similar lifestyle, and offer loads of travelling advice and tips on their blog. A photo posted by Nick & Dariece (@goatsontheroad) on Apr 22, 2015 at 5:57pm PDT 
“If you really want change, then just jump towards a world of freedom and adventure. Don’t put it off another day,” Wharton said. 
“Once you take the plunge, there are always safety nets that appear to cushion your fall. 
“One thing is for sure, if you’re heading on the right path in your life, then everything will work out and fall into place.”
